text: I swallow the sound of the door latch and pull on my coat before following her out. The night wind cuts like a blade, snow stinging against my face.
She walks fast, never looking back—like she’s already assumed I’ll follow, or like she’s gambling that I won’t.
I soften my steps, careful not to let my boots scrape against the ice. It’s strange—I’ve never trained in stealth, yet my body moves as if I’ve practiced this countless times.
“Stay close.”
“I won’t slow you down.”
She doesn’t reply. She just shifts her cloak slightly so I can see the path she’s taking—not along the streets, but through the ‘gaps’ between them.
We avoid two lamplit roads and slip into an unused alley. Frosted iron nails jut from the walls like teeth. There’s a faint burnt smell in the air.
“Echo Circle members are inside.”
“What do you need me to do?”
She finally glances sideways at me—quick, sharp—like assessing whether I deserve to survive the next minute.
“Hold the alley mouth.”
“If someone runs out—don’t fight. Just call my name.”
“That’s it?”
“That’s it.”
She presses a small bundle into my palm: cold, hard powder—like ground bone.
“Listen carefully.”
“Your job isn’t to fight.”
“It’s to make sure they don’t see you as a target.”
Then she turns and disappears into the darkness. Her cloak flickers once—like a slit cut through the snow.
From deeper in the alley comes the faint sound of metal—short, precise. Like someone deleting a line of conversation.
I press my back against the wall, forcing myself not to move. All I hear is my heartbeat and the hiss of falling snow.
Suddenly, a figure staggers out of the alley. Black robe. A dark ring marking the chest.
“Stop!”
I don’t charge him. I fling the powder at his feet. The moment it hits the snow, pale smoke bursts upward.
He stumbles, choking, doubling over. In the next second, a streak of silver flashes from within the alley.
“Don’t touch him.”
Her blade rests at his throat—clean and absolute, like the ending was written before it began.
He tries to speak. Her wrist turns once—and silence claims him.
Alicia tears a thin chain from beneath his collar. The pendant glints faintly.
“Not it.”
She frowns—annoyed at wasted time. Then she looks at me, her voice low but clear.
“You did well.”
The praise is brief—but it feels like permission.
She slips the chain inside her cloak.
“Move. Next location.”
